desc: DNMT3B encodes a DNA methyltransferase involved in embryonic development, imprinting, and X chromosome inactivation. Germline mutations of DNMT3B are associated with immunodeficiency, centromere instability and facial anomalies (ICF) syndrome.

The DNMT3B gene encodes DNA methyltransferase 3B, an enzyme catalyzing the addition of methyl groups to cytosines within CpG dinucleotides (PMID: 21243710). DNMT3B is essential for the establishment of epigenetics patterns during development and its loss results in an early embryonic lethal phenotype (PMID: 10555141). It is involved in gene silencing through DNA methylation, including imprinted genes, genes on the inactive X chromosome and repetitive sequences, as well as through methylation-independent transcriptional co-repression (PMID: 17616512, 17708532, 22956494). All DNMTs play an important role in maintaining chromosomal integrity (PMID: 21927626). Biallelic mutations in DNMT3B are associated with ICF (immunodeficiency, centromeric instability and facial abnormalities) syndrome (PMID: 10647011, 16501171). Mutations of the DNMT3B gene are distributed throughout its open reading frame, a pattern consistent with the loss-of-function hypothesis. Dysregulated expression of DNMTs and aberrant DNA methylation patterns (both hypo- and hypermethylation) are found in various cancer types at low frequencies (PMID: 21941284, 22037554, 22895193; cBioPortal, MSKCC, March 2015). Promoter CpG island hypermethylation is implicated in transcriptional silencing of tumor suppressor genes, while global DNA hypomethylation may be linked to genomic instability and to de-repression of stem cell genes and proto-oncogenes.
